story: EAST Lothian played host to a distinguished guest as the Princess Royal made a special visit to the county.Her Royal Highness Princess Anne paid a visit to Leuchie House, the respite care centre near North Berwick which offers respite breaks for people with a iety of long-term conditions as well as their carers, last Thursday.The Princess Royal previously visited Leuchie in  and launched the lsquoLeuchie Forever Fundrsquo, a new fundraising initiative for the charity, of which she became patron. She also visited in .On her latest visit, the Princess ndash who was described as a ldquolovely lassie by one guest ndash was greeted by Mark Bevan, chief executive, and Bob Brannan, chair of the fund, and taken to meet Leuchiersquos guests, staff, supporters, patrons and trustees.The meeting was held in Leuchiersquos lounge, with a series of paintings hanging on the walls created by Rachel Mylne, who had turned  two days prior to the royal visit.Money raised by the Leuchie Forever Fund had allowed the lounge to be redecorated, and when hanging the paintings on the wall a signature from the s, a mark from a previous painter, was discovered.On her arrival at Leuchie, Princess Anne first met some of the guests and their carers. She asked questions including ldquoHow did you find out about this place  and ldquoHow long have you been coming here  She listened to their stories and the dference Leuchie had made in their lives.Moving on to the trustees, donors and patrons, she was interested in hearing how they had discovered Leuchie and how they had become involved in the charity.Among those present was Scottish rugby legend Gavin Hastings, who is also a patron of Leuchie.Describing his involvement in the charity, he said: ldquoItrsquos a great place to come along and itrsquos great to support the work that they do here because they do such great work ndash not just here in Leuchie but all over Scotland.After meeting the Princess, many praised her humour and willingness to take the time and talk to everyone, listening to their stories. Others mentioned how hardworking and well-briefed she was and how much she knew about Leuchie.Regular guest Iain Elder described the Princess as ldquoa lovely lassie, while others praised her interest and passion for the charity.Jim Maxwell, who is the primary carer for we Jane, a guest at Leuchie, said of his conversation with the Princess: ldquoShe asked where we lived and how we managed to find Leuchie House. I told her as a carer it is very important for the both of us to come here.ldquoShe really took the time to speak to us and hear our story.Afterwards, some of the guests gave a speech where they explained how much Leuchie House had helped them.Alex MacCarthy-Morrogh has multiple sclerosis and visits Leuchie every Tuesday as a day guest. As well as attending physio and fitness classes, which he describes as essential for his physical and mental wellbeing, he talks to fellow guests to keep them company.He said: ldquoI come here to help myself and to give my we a break and give her some freedom. Me being here, she knows Irsquom safe which is very important to me.ldquoThis place is important to the people here, therersquos no other place like it. They treat you like a person and see you beyond the wheelchair.His we Susie said: ldquoItrsquos great when Alex comes here. Falling is his biggest concern and I donrsquot worry he is going to fall when he is here. Him being safe is so important to me and they really look after him and everyone here.Mairi OrsquoKeefe, patron and former chief executive of Leuchie House, said: ldquoPrincess Anne loves the work we do here and the respiratory things that we do everyone gets physio and everyone gets a respiratory assessment. She also sees what it does for the guests.ldquoShe really cares about Leuchie.A tour of Leuchie followed, with Princess Anne meeting one volunteer who wrote the calligraphy on the invites and who gave the Princess a humorous wink.When speaking to the dieticians, Princess Anne expressed how dficult it must be to keep up with a iety of dferent diets.She took an interest in one, a soon-to-be graduate, asking about her experience in Leuchie in relation to her studies and saying: ldquoYoursquove probably come across more diets here than on your course!Her tour led on to the art room, while in the TV room Princess Anne met one guest who had been coming to Leuchie since , jokingly saying: ldquoYoursquore keeping them on their toes!The Princess was taken into a further lounge and met a man taking part in a virtual reality experience.When she noticed he was in London, she said: ldquoI know London very well. She was told he caught a whale earlier ndash ldquonot in the Thames, I hope, she replied.Mark Bevan, chief executive of Leuchie, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to welcome HRH The Princess Royal, and patron of the Leuchie Forever Fund, to Leuchie House once again and for her to meet and thank our many supporters.ldquoShe saw first-hand the importance of providing quality respite to our guests and their carers.ldquoThe visit was a wonderful experience for our guests and colleagues who were able to spend time with Her Royal Highness. She spoke to them about their experiences and the dference that spending time at Leuchie makes to their lives and those of their carers.Bob Brannan, chairman of the Leuchie Forever Fund, said: ldquoThe Princess has taken time since becoming our patron three years ago to really understand Leuchie.ldquoToday as on previous occasions, she has used this understanding to encourage our many generous supporters to ensure Leuchie can continue to develop and provide such a great service to so many people across Scotland for years to come.As the visit came to an end, the Princess signed the visitorsrsquo book and was presented flowers and a card by Rachel Mylne, who said: ldquoThank you for all your hard work, we are very grateful. Leuchie is a wonderful place, will you try and keep it going Princess Anne replied: ldquoI will definitely try my best.

title: thousands-expected-attend-aberdeen-standard-investments-scottish-open-renaissance-club
story: Thousands of fans are expected to flock to East Lothianrsquos Golf Coast between today and Sunday as the competition heats up.Among those taking part are four-time Major winners Rory McIlroy and Ernie Els, Scotlandrsquos last Major champion Paul Lawrie and former world number one Justin Thomas.Brandon Stone, who won the tournament at nearby Gullane Golf Club  months ago, is joined by Rickie Fowler, who lted the title at the same club in .Action gets under way at .am with Joakim Lagergren, Oliver Wilson and Scott Henry taking to the course.North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest also has an early start as his bid for the title begins at .am alongside Matthieu Pavon and Andy Sullivan.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale tees off at .pm alongside Andrew Johnston and Erik Van Rooyen, with McIlroy and Fowler playing alongside Robert MacIntyre from .pm.The final round of the day tees off at .pm with Steven Brown, Ben Evans and Justin Walters taking to the course.The Pro-Am was played at the course yesterday .

title: new-homes-over-60s-longniddry-welcomed
story: East Lothian Council gave the go-ahead for nearly  new houses in three separate applications to its planning committee.One application for four houses and  flats revealed that all its units would be for older people.The housing, which is on land identied for potentially having up to  new homes on it, to the south of Longniddry, will be taken by Castle Rock Edin Housing Association once built.A planning application before the committee revealed: ldquoAll of the residential units would be for independent living for people aged over  years.The flats will mainly be in two-storey buildings, with one three-storey building and four bungalows which will be built around a courtyard-style quadrangle.Two additional applications included one for  houses and  flats, all of which will be for private sale, and another for  houses and  flats, of which only two houses and eight flats will be affordable.Places for People, which is overseeing the over-s housing and  private properties, welcomed the decision as the ldquofirst phase in the Longniddry South development.Willie Lockhart, Places for People interim director of development for Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have the go-ahead to begin building at Longniddry. It promises to be a truly special development offering benefits to both new and existing residents of the village.The layout of the development, on land owned by the Wemyss and March Estate, sees housing designed by architect Ben Pentreath to reflect traditional East Lothian homes, and the committee was shown a walkthrough video depicting what the streets will look like.Ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoI welcome the decision to provide affordable housing for over-s in Longniddry.ldquoIt is an issue for people wanting to downsize from their properties which are then freed up for families who want to move in.Representatives of Longniddry Community Council attended the meeting to raise concerns about some of the infrastructure surrounding the new housing. But they told the committee they had no objections to the development itself.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, encouraged the community council to contact the local authority with any concerns about issues during the development of the new housing.And council leader Willie Innes praised the members of the community council for attending.He said: ldquoThe community council raise valid concern which will need to be addressed by the developers. They are not opposing it in principle and we want to work with the community to manage the process.He added: ldquoI think this development is something special and something dferent and will make a positive impact on Longniddry and East Lothian.Rock Feilding-Mellen, from Socially Conscious Capital, which worked with the landowners to develop a masterplan for the entire site, welcomed the plansrsquo approval.He said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Zero C can now start building these much-needed new homes and turning our carefully designed masterplan and design code into a beautul st-century extension to Longniddry.ldquoWe trust that residents and members of the wider community who contributed throughout the many consultations will feel that their time and effort has paid off when they finally get to see the results.

title: knox-academy-half-marathon-team-raise-2-000
story: Eleven S pupils were joined by half a dozen members of staff at the Edinburgh Marathon Festivalrsquos half-marathon start line.The Knox Academy group all donned special t-shirts highlighting they were running for East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme .The school has formed a strong bond with the charity, which provides full-day playschemes during school holidays for children aged five to  with a wide range of special needs disabilities, and previously secured pound, for the good cause through a Youth Philanthropy Initiativescheme.Lana Borwick, PE teacher, was among those taking part.She said: ldquoThere was a real sense of community around the event.ldquoAll the participants took to the lsquoPink Penrsquo to give each other final words of support and encouragement before the early start on the day.ldquoAlmost all of the Knox Academy runners were making their half marathon debut which was a real test of their commitment to training and they didnrsquot disappoint, with everyone completing the challenge despite the poor weather conditions ndash some in remarkable times!ldquoIt was a wonderful occasion and we are all very proud of what wersquove managed to achieve together, ultimately impacting on the opportunities that the playscheme can continue to provide to youngsters in our community.ldquoIt was great also to see so many people brave the weather to come out and cheer us on, both from our school community and from the Playscheme, which really helped as the legs started to tire!ldquoEvents like this serve as a fantastic reminder to us of the commitment, enthusiasm and drive that our young people have to make a dference in society.Joining Miss Borwick, who completed the .-mile course in a time of :., at the finish line were pupils Matthew Black , Dylan Brotherston , Isabelle Bowen , Elliot Cochrane , Harry Cunningham , Hana Elder , Adam Fairgrieve , Mateusz Juchniewicz , Max Leveque , Daniel Mackinnonand Lauren Taylor , as well as Robert Flood, Susanne Fox, Thomas Salkeld, Suzie Stewart and Alex Redford .Kirsty Milne of ELSNP was ldquoblown away by the support.She said: ldquoThe team have signicantly raised our charityrsquos profile by embarking on such a tremendous fundraiser and we are extremely thankful to them for the incredible amount raised.ldquoWe have strengthened links with Knox Academy over the years, with many of their pupils past and present volunteering at or attending our playscheme and youth club provisions and it is amazing to see the school uniting to support our local cause.ldquoWe cannot thank the runners enough for their incredible efforts and for raising such a large sum of money.ldquoOur playschemes will be running for the full six weeks of the summer break and, thanks to the generous donations from the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, we will be able to offer many fun trips and outings to those attending.ldquoThere is something really special about seeing local young people coming together to support their peers and we are thankful to all at Knox Academy for their support.

title: bid-third-pharmacy-tranent-turned
story: The application was presented to the Pharmacy Practice Committee , which decided that the town was already suitably served by its current pharmacies.The committee also stated that there was too long a wait between the Consultation Analyst Reportand the hearing as over a year had passed, which it felt rendered the findings out of date.Representatives from the current Tranent pharmacies ndash Lloyds Pharmacy and Well Tranent, both on High Street ndash were present at the committee hearing and both claimed that they had already addressed any issues that were raised in the consultation and therefore problems raised by the CAR were no longer applicable.There was also a question over whether the premises planned for the new pharmacy at  Bridge Street would be large enough to support the planned two consultation rooms and dispensary area, which the committee felt raised the issue of whether appropriate confidentiality was possible.Letters of support for the pharmacy were submitted by Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council and ward councillor Kenny McLeod among others however, the committee felt that none of these letters ldquospecied needs which were currently not being met.Pharmacy applicant Niamh Morrison visited the community council to thank members for their support over the process and to assure them that she would be launching an appeal.She said: ldquoI am of course very disappointed.ldquoI really believe that this community needs this, and I have developed a real soft spot for the area.ldquoThe appeal process unfortunately wonrsquot be quick, it could take years.ldquoI just wanted to thank you all for the support that you have given us.The rejection comes not long after Tranent Medical Practice announced that it would be suspending advanced appointments due to a shortage of GPrsquos.Robert McNeill, a member of the community council, said: ldquoFrom a personal point of view, Irsquom very disappointed.ldquoTranent surgery is not unique in its problems and the pharmacy could have added extra services within the community.David Forrest, chairman of the community council added with regards the letter that the group had drafted to support the application: ldquoThe letters that we wrote came from the heart, we really feel that this was what was best for our community.ldquoWe are incredibly disappointed with the decision, and fully support Niamh in her appeal.ldquoWe will be writing to our local MP and MSP to register our frustration at the situation.ldquoThe decision is very short-sighted.The decision comes as planning permission in principle has been approved for  houses at Windygoul South, though the committee determined that both Lloyds and Well Tranent were able to increase capacity should ldquoproposed housebuilding occur locally.Ward councillor Kenny McLeod said: ldquoWith the new houses on their way, the town will need extra pharmacies and more GPs.ldquoIrsquom so disappointed that the pharmacy has been rejected, I really think we need one.

title: matt-kuchar-among-four-players-tied-scottish-open-lead-first-day
story: Kuchar shot an eight-under-par  in todays first round, leaving him tied with Frenchman Romain Wattel and Italian duo Edoardo Molinari and Nino Bertasio.Other big names who impressed were Swedens Henrik Stenton and Englishman Ian Poulter, who finished two shots behind the leaders, as did Richie Ramsay, who is the top-placed Scot after the first round.East Lothians Grant Forrest also had a fine showing, finishing with a four-under-par , the same total as four-time Major winner Rory McIlroy.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale finished a shot further back but it also in good shape to make the cut with a similar round in tomorrows second day of play.

title: pictures-regiment-receives-historic-honour-parading-dunbar
story: Members of the public lined the streets in Dunbar on Saturday as a special presentation and parade took place to mark the historic moment involving the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.The regimentrsquos links with East Lothian date back to  with the formation of the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry.The Dunbar, Seton, Salton and Gford troops eventually disbanded and joined with other areas before reforming in  under the current name.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, conferred the Freedom of East Lothian to the Yeomanry, represented by Major Stuart Vine, in the shadow of Lauderdale House, the Regimentrsquos original home.Mr Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoAs well as being a landmark building on Dunbarrsquos High Street, Lauderdale House is the historic home of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.ldquoIt is therefore appropriate that we are celebrating this occasion here in its shadow.ldquoThe Freedom of East Lothian is the highest honour our council can award.ldquoIt recognises those who play an important role here: those who represent our county and its values, contribute to the fabric of our civic society or who are integral to the history and tradition of East Lothian.ldquoIn granting the Freedom to the Lothians and Border Yeomanry today, the Regiment joins the Royal Scots Borderers st Battalion, renowned artist John Bellany and golf champion Catriona Matthew as worthy recipients of this rarely-bestowed tribute.ldquoLast weekend, our nation came together to commemorate Armed Services Day, which marks the important part that the Armed Services have played, and continue to play, in our society.ldquoToday we come together as a county to pay our particular thanks to the members of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry for the part it has played in East Lothian since its earliest roots as the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry in .ldquoIt is extraordinary to think that the regiment has represented East Lothian in every conflict since the Napoleonic Wars, including the Great War.Following the presentation, the regiment paraded along Dunbarrsquos High Street, saluting Mr Goodfellow outside the Town House, before continuing on to its war memorial outside Dunbar Parish Church on the townrsquos Queenrsquos Road for a rededication ceremony.Representatives from the council, serving and veteran members of the Armed Services community and their families, support organisations and crowds of well-wishers witnessed the occasion.Granting the Freedom of East Lothian to the regiment recognises the sacrices and service made by its members over the years, and reinforces the councilrsquos commitment to all armed services members living within the county.Major SJ Vine, Squadron Leader, ESquadron, The Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, said the squadron was ldquotruly honoured to be given the Freedom of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThe day marks the reinvigoration of the strong partnership between the community and the squadron from which many of those serving, have served or represented through our long history and antecedent regiments live and work ndash we are grateful for the enduring support.ldquoIt is signicant and fitting that we are able to parade through Dunbar and also rededicate the war memorial in what is our spiritual home.ldquo[It was] a truly proud and memorable day and one which reconnects the lsquoCountyrsquos Regimentrsquo with the community whom we serve.The presentation and parade were part of a day of celebration of the regiment and Armed Services held in the town.A civic reception was held at the Town House for the Yeomanry and its supporters where a framed lsquoFreedom of East Lothianrsquo certicate was presented.The British Legion hosted a family event at its club for  people, while Dunbar Museum hosted a special one-day exhibition of the Yeomanryrsquos military treasures.

title: car-submerged-tide-north-berwick-beach
story: The incident, which took place on Sunday, required the assistance of the townrsquos RNLI, who had to tow the car out using their leboat tractor.The incident attracted plenty of attention, with many people stopping to take a look at the car being recovered.Eyewitness Derek Braid said: ldquoThe problem started when the owner of the car was recovering a RIB from the sea.ldquoThe car became stuck on the soft sand on the beach at the West Bay and the incoming tide engulfed the car.When the RNLI arrived, crew members attached a rope from the tractor to the car.After a number of attempts and plenty of pushing by the leboat crew and the other people nearby, the car was eventually successfully towed out of the water and taken to safety on the Elcho Green slipway.

title: degree-delight-ex-leuchie-chief
story: Mairi OrsquoKeefe was awarded a lsquoDegree of Doctor of the University, Honoris Causarsquo at a graduation ceremony in the Usher Hall in Edinburgh on Tuesday.She celebrated alongside Prue Leith, The Great British Bake Off judge and chancellor at Musselburgh-based QMU.Mairi is the former chief executive of Leuchie House, a respite care centre near North Berwick that provides care for those suffering from long-term neurological conditions and their families.She took over the helm at Leuchie in  when it was operated by the MS Society however, this was not her first experience in management as she has held ious airport manager and change manager roles.She helped save the centre from closure in  after setting up the lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign and building support for the centre.The campaign gained enough backing to allow Leuchie to become an independent charity.Over the next seven years, Mairi and her team secured pound. million in grants from trust funds and donations from members of the public, as well as support from the Scottish Government, delivering more than , respite nights.Mairi sat on cross-party groups in the Scottish Parliament, was vice-chair of the Health and Social Alliance Scotland and a member of the Governing Council for Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce.In  she was awarded lsquoCommunity Champion of the yearrsquo in STVrsquos lsquoFinding Scotlandrsquos Real Heroesrsquo awards. Two years later, she received an MBE for services to people with disabilities.Mairi has helped establish an official partnership with QMU, which has been in place since . The partnership has allowed for clinical and work placements, research and creative opportunities to be provided to many students, including nurses, film students, dietetics, physiotherapy and gastronomy.Mairi announced her retirement last year.Professor Petra Wend, principal and vice-chancellor of QMU, said: ldquoWe are delighted that our students had the opportunity to learn about the career of this former nursing and social care leader and to be inspired by her achievements and her compassion for others.ldquoWe are proud to recognise Mairi as a hard-working advocate for people living with disabilities across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWe celebrated her achievements as a leader and her success in integrating healthcare with respite services.

title: schoolteacher-recreates-law-primary-school-lego
story: The P pupils were invited to make their own creations to join supply teacher Malcolm Piriersquos recreation of the primary school at the Awesome Bricks event as it took pride of place at the exhibition.And Malcolm said he was delighted by the efforts of the youngsters, who came up with an array of designs for the weekend event.The opportunity was a chance for Malcolm, , to bring his passion for Lego to the classroom and inspire youngsters with what he hopes can become a valuable teaching resource in the future.An enthusiast since he was a young boy, Malcolm knows first-hand the impact the modelling bricks can have on children.When he was a nine-year-old living in Abu Dhabi, UAE, he took first place in a Lego competition organised to promote learning through the creative art and sending him and his family on atrip to Legoland in Billund, Denmark, where he became an honorary citizen.Nearly four decades later, Malcolm has brought his enthusiasm for Lego to schools where he has been working, and encouraged children at Law Primary to get involved when he was given the chance to take part in the exhibition at East Fortune.It is not the first time that he has captured youngstersrsquo imagination at the school with Lego and, during a stint there in , he amazed youngsters with some of the models created.And it was his knowledge of the school which inspired his model of the building, which he said had taken him a week of intensive work to put together.Malcolm told the Courier: ldquoIn previous times at the school, I spent time as a playground supervisor as well as in the classroom and knew the building well.ldquoI thought it would be a good model to recreate and people would recognise it.And his efforts impressed Jill Wareham, Law Primary Schoolrsquos headteacher.She said: ldquoWe were all really impressed by the Lego model of Law Primary School.It was very recognisable as our school ndash right down to the miniature Law in the playground.Supply teacher Malcolm is hoping to use his expertise with Lego to create future projects which could provide learning opportunities for youngsters.He said: ldquoIrsquom trying to focus on things from a dferent angle and will be looking to use Lego exclusively as a teaching resource and will work on developing activities and lessons on that basis.ldquoWhether I can make a viable business out of that is something Irsquoll be finding out soon.

title: please-don-39-t-ask-don-39-t-always-use-wheelchair
story: Laura Oliver was diagnosed with Functional Neurological Disorderaged .The -year-old, originally from Cornwall, has lived in Haddington for three years but feels people do not understand the condition, the symptoms of which include fatigue, loss of balance, memory problems and seizures.She said: ldquoIt is incredibly common [but] even within hospitals, the condition is not well advocated at all.ldquoI would be using a wheelchair about  per cent of the time. The rest of the time, I use a long cane because of my eyesight or my mobility scooter.ldquoI can get total paralysis and be stuck in bed for weeks at a time.On first finding out she had the condition, Laura said: ldquoI got very, very clumsy.ldquoAt first, I did not put it down to anything and just thought I was not very co-ordinated. Then I started to get fatigue and had to use a wheelchair.Other symptoms included a loss of sight, as well as the need to use catheters.Originally, doctors diagnosed Laura with multiple sclerosis.She said: ldquoI was then told it was part of a depressive illness and I would get better.ldquoThen I met Dr Stoneand he was that one that said FND. It is le-limiting but not le-threatening.Laura, who grew up wanting to be a nurse in the navy, told the Courier how receiving a diagnosis had actually helped open up a community where she could discuss the condition.However, she said not everyone was so understanding, with people often questioningshe truly had a condition.She said: ldquoI have had people say to me lsquoI saw you walking one day and the next minute you are in a wheelchairrsquo.ldquoOn another occasion, I have had somebody saying it was mental health. They would say it is all in my head and that I need to see a psychiatrist.But she was quick to praise the work of groups such as Our Community Kitchen, which tackles social isolation through bringing people together three days a week for a three-course meal, and outreach programme Friday Friends.Dawn Golder, executive director of FND Hope, which aims to promote awareness of FND and support for anyone affected by the condition, said: ldquoUnfortunately, FND whilst common, is still highly stigmatised and many healthcare and medical professionals still think it is all in the patientrsquos lsquoheadrsquo.ldquoI think the issue is in relation to historical names for FND.ldquoResearch has now proven that many people with FND do not have to have a psychological psychiatric element to their diagnosis.

title: construction-work-waste-incinerator-near-dunbar-now-complete
story: Final tests are being carried out at the energy recovery facilityat Oxwellmains, with low-carbon energy already being generated at the site, to the south-west of Dunbar.The completion of Viridorrsquos ERF marks the latest milestone in a project delivering a , tonne per year energy recovery facility to Scotland.A key part of the poundm investment by Viridor in Scotland, the ERF will ert non-recyclable waste from landfill in line with the Scottish Governmentrsquos ambitions and contribute to Scottish energy security.More than  contractors put in more than two-million man hours to the project, with more than  workers on site at its peak.Scott Reynolds, Dunbar ERF operations manager, said that the site had already started generating low-carbon energy for the national grid and, over the course of the coming year, would create MW of base-load low-carbon energy direct to the electricity grid.The energy generated ndash which, according to Viridor, is comparable to  wind turbines ndash is enough to continuously power , homes.Mr Reynolds said: ldquoViridor is pleased to be working with the Scottish local authorities and businesses to put non-recyclable waste to work.ldquoWith the construction phase of the project now complete, we are carrying out final plant testing as we process non-recyclable waste, using this as the fuel to create electricity.ldquoThe new facility includes a visitorsrsquo centre, where we look forward to welcoming interested groups to encourage the next generation to put the right stuff in the right bin.ldquoWe will be talking about recycling here at the plant because we want to ensure valuable recycling opportunities are not missed.ldquoThe waste which comes here should only be waste which cannot be recycled, allowing us to attach a purpose to it through energy recovery.The plant is constructed on , piles, or vertical foundations, upon which sit more than , tonnes of concrete and steel to support the processing equipment of the -metre-high building.The facility features two boilers, each processing  tonnes of waste each hour, and managed and controlled through km of pipework and km of cabling.Waste received at Dunbar ERF will include residual household waste from East Lothian Council, as well as the local authorities in North and South Lanarkshire, in addition to non-recyclable commercial collections from Edinburgh and the Lothians.

title: bernd-wiesberger-wins-scottish-open-play-off-drama
story: The Austrian held a two-shot lead going into todayrsquosfinal round.However, he needed to dig deep to take the title at The Renaissance Club after a play-off battle with Benjamin Hebert.Andrew Johnstonrsquos - took him to - for the tournament and set an early marker.Then, Wiesberger and Hebert traded the lead over the afternoon in what was a preview of the play-off.Wiesberger edged into the lead with two holes to go but a bogey on the th saw him drop back to -.Frenchman Hebert, who secured a spot at The Open through his performance in East Lothian, had already wrapped up his fourth round by that point and had the advantage of being able to sit back and watch how the other players handled the pressure.His final round  ndash a score matched by Johnston ndash gave him a good chance of winning the title.In the end, all eyes were on the par four th hole, with Wiesberger needing par to force a play-off.He took his time over the vital putt, which he sank to ensure the drama would continue.Seventy-two holes could not decide an outright winner, which meant the need to play the th hole again.In the first play-off, it looked like advantage Hebert after a fine second shot but Wiesberger secured par.Hebert had a putt to take the title but could not do it and had to settle for a par of his own to force a second play-off hole.The Frenchman had a second opportunity but again it was not to be and both men made their journey back to the th tee for a third play-off hole.Finally, Wiesberger wrapped up the victory in the fading light.Elsewhere, North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest finished on an impressive - earlier in the day.A final round of  saw him pick up six birdies over the course with two bogeys along the way.The score was good enough for a tie of rd, one position behind last yearrsquos winner Brandon Stone and Rory McIlroy.He was East Lothianrsquos last representative, with David Drysdale cut after the third round yesterday .The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil scored  in his third round, which saw him finish the tournament on - title: nicola-sturgeon-party-ruined-scotland---go

title: big-yins-greatest-ever-comedy-routines-published-first-time
story: The comic has agreed a deal with a publisher for a new book called Tall Tales And Wee Stories which will feature classic yarns such as The Last Supper, Jojoba Shampoo, Incontinence Pants and Shouting at Wildebeest.Despite a -year stand-up career, the stories he tells on stage have not previously been released in written form.The book will be published in October by Two Roads.It comes after the Big Yin, who is suffering from Parkinsonrsquos disease, announced his retirement from stand-up last December.:Sir Billy Connolly chants with Glaswegians in New YorkConnolly, , will be writing a new introduction for the book, which will be illustrated by his artwork.He said: ldquoI was a storyteller long before I was a comedian. Coming from Glasgow, itrsquos weird, I donrsquot really tell jokes, like Irish jokes and all that, I tell wee stories.ldquoIrsquove been asked many times to put them down in a book and Irsquove always refused.ldquoIt didnrsquot seem right because as long as I was still performing live then I was still playing around with my stories ndash pulling them apart, twisting them around, improvising and improving.ldquoBut in December of last year, I decided to retire from live stand-up. So, this feels like the right moment to put these stories down, once and for all. Itrsquos always been a pleasure talking to you. I hope now itrsquoll be a pleasure reading me.The blurb for the book reads: ldquoBillyrsquos routines always felt spontaneous. He improvised, embellished and digressed as he went: a two-minute anecdote could become a -minute routine by the next night of a tour. And he brought a beautul sense of the absurd to his shows as he rfed on holidays, alcohol, the crucixion, or naked bungee jumping.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoBut Billyrsquos comedy could be laced with anger too. He hated pretentiousness and called out hypocrisy where ever he saw it.ldquoHe loved to shock, and his startling appearance gave him license to say anything he damn well pleased about sex, politics or religion. It was only because he was so likeable that he got it away. Billy had the popular touch. His comedy spanned generations and dferent social tribes in a way that few others have ever managed.Nick Davies, managing director at John Murray Press who acquired the rights for publishing house Two Roads, said: ldquoAs his many millions of fans will know, Billyrsquos stories can be rude, warm-hearted, anarchic, joyful, angry, far-fetched, down-to-earth and everything in between.ldquoThey are also beautully constructed, brilliantly paced and deeply funny.

title: perils-living-close-one-scotland-s-new-unadopted-streets
story: Murray Wilson has just clambered in to the cellar of his pre-war Cambuslang semi.Squatting, the -year-old shoogles a dipstick in the basementrsquos concrete floor. Lting it out, he can see the damp in his housersquos earthen sump.He can smell it too. ldquoItrsquos like walking by a river, ldquo he says, ldquoitrsquos like fresh water . It attracts flies, itrsquos not very nice.Since  Mr Wilson, a gas engineer, has been regularly lowering himself in to the hole under to house to check he is not being flooded.FULL STORY:Thousands of Scots in legal limbo as roads unadoptedHe has a couple of pumps - one of which switches on automatically when the usual damp turns to full-flow cascade of rainwater. And Mr Wilson always knows when it is going to get bad, a day or two after the heavens open.There had been no history of flooding on the property on Eastfield Avenue, where Mr Wilson has lived for  years. What changed  The Hawthorn Estate was built.Murray Wilson in his cellar, picture by Colin MearnsJust up the a brae from his semi are neat rows of tightly packed new-build white homes. This used to be a grassy, partially wooded hill. Now it is asphalted over.Everybody knows this is where the water comes from. Mr Wilson, clutching a small plastic container, explains how. ldquoThis is dye, he says. ldquoWorkers came and poured in to drains up in the Hawthorn estate. And, sure enough, it eventually turned up here.The hill acted ldquolike a sponge, Mr Wilson says. ldquoIt was a natural green belt. I never thought there would be houses on it because it was a slope.Barratt was the builder. They have been trying to fix snagging on their drains for years. Things, Mr Wilson says, are getting better. The flooding is not as extreme was it once was.FULL STORY:Thousands of Scots in legal limbo as roads unadoptedThe local council, South Lanarkshire, has not been, so far, impressed. Officials have sucked their teeth and told Barratt they will not ldquoadopt the roads until the drainage problems are solved.How Mr Wilson pumps out his cellarWhich means that a decade after the white houses went up, the roads, Hawthorn Way and Hawthorn Avenue, are still the responsibility of the builder, not the council.These streets are among hundreds in Scotland stuck in a legal limbo between developers and councils.Mr Wilson is also in a kind of limbo. He does not want to sell his home. But he could not do so evenhe did.ldquoThere would need to be a home report and they would see all this, he says, waving at goods stacked on pallets to keep them dry. ldquoThe floor has all eroded through the water. ldquoThe new Hawthorn EstateBut Mr Wilson has sympathy for neighbours whose streets are not adopted. In England similar issues have hit house prices and left whole communities with substandard services. In Scotland - where there are thought to be some , new homes on streets still to be adopted - the issues has barely been recognised.Mr Wilson says: ldquoThroughout Scotland there are lots of people who buy a house and think everything is fine, the drainage is fine and the road is adopted.ldquoBut then - lo and behold - it turns out they are not because they have not submitted the proper drawings or it is not fit for purpose.FULL STORY:Thousands of Scots in legal limbo as roads unadoptedThere is hope of a resolution in the Cambuslang case. Gordon Mackay, Head of Roads and Transportation at South Lanarkshire Council, told The Herald ldquoWe are in dialogue with Barratt Homes and Scottish Water in an attempt to have them resolve the outstanding deficiencies in the drainage system that would allow Hawthorn Way and Hawthorn Avenue to be adopted. We are currently awaiting confirmation that necessary remedial works have been satisfactorily completed.Hawthorn EstateDavid Scott, managing director, Barratt West Scotland said: ldquoWe are working with Scottish Water and South Lanarkshire Council to resolve offsite works to improve the drainage, which will hopefully be completed by year end, allowing the local authority to take ownership of the roads affected. We are sorry for any inconvenience this has caused.Mr Wilson, in his cellar, has been waiting a long time. ldquoMyself and my neighbours are still not happy, he says.ldquoAll the modications they have done have really helped but I am still using gallons of disinfectant to take away that smell.ldquoAnd I have had years of worry. Rain is not like it used to be. The climate is changing. Now you get a monsoon any time.And that, for Mr Wilson, means pumping out his cellar.

title: thousands-scots-legal-limbo-roads-unadopted
story: As many as , new-build houses are on roads which have not been "adopted" by local councils because they are substandard, previously unpublished figures suggest.That means many residents are living for years on defacto "private" roads while developers unsnag problems with drains, lighting and surfaces.In England, campaigners believe such problems are forcing house sellers to offer discounts on price.:The perils of living close to one of Scotlandrsquos new but unadopted streetsLabour MSP James Kelly believes the scale of the issue means Scottish authorities need to get on top of it.Mr Kelly has been supporting constituents affected by a decade-long saga in Cambuslang, where the local South Lanarkshire Council has refused to adopt a new Barratt scheme after people in nearby streets suffered flooding.He said: "The experience of locals in Cambuslang shines a light on the issue of how lsquounadoptedrsquo roads can disrupt the lives of people in neighbouring streets in established communities."It is clear the problem is becoming more widespread and houses are being erected without proper consideration being given to the surrounding infrastructure."The issue needs to be carefully examined by councils and the Scottish Government. "The current regulations are clearly inadequate and a proper process for housing completions needs to ensure that new and existing residents are not adversely affected by new developments."James Kelly MSPThe Scottish numbers have been calculated by an architect and retired senior strategic planner who has peppered local authorities with Freedom of Information requests.:The perils of living close to one of Scotlandrsquos new but unadopted streetsDave Sutton, who is also a former Labour councillor in Bristol, reckons there are now some , new homes which are not on adopted road.He added: "My summation is that some % of these will move through the adoption process - but which can often take  to  years. So more than ,likely to be with an adoption problem."Ever since  Scottish councils have taken over privately built roads from housing developers - as long as they meet standards.Public sector insiders stress that adoption can be a long and drawn-out process as roads officials pressurise developers to get their streets up to scratch.Cash-strapped councils already have a huge backlog in roads and lighting repairs and do no want to take on extra work and costs that should have been done by private builders.Getting precise figures on how many people or homes are affected by non-adopted roads is almost impossible.That is because dferent councils count the issue in dferent ways. Glasgow, for example, as of , had  development sites were roads were not adopted. Neighbouring East Dunbartonshire had  developments with around  homes. Falkirk, again as of , had one road that was still to be adopted  years after it was built.This is on top of the many pre- private roads already scattered across Scotland - where homeowners are expected to pay the upkeep.Stewart Turner, of the Ayrshire Roads Alliance, chairs the Society of Chief Officers of Transportation in Scotland. He said: "Owners of private roads may request that their road be adopted by the roads authority and provided this road joins the public road and it is to a standard acceptable to the roads authority, then it would be adopted."Also roads authorities may ask the frontagers of private roads to make improvement and they may,they consider appropriate, contribute to this cost. "Throughout Scotland the ious Roads Authorities have a dferent approach to this power."However taking into account the Roads Authoritiesrsquo primary responsibility to maintain the public roads then it is considered important that the available resource is directed to the public roads. Additional financial resource would be required to improve the extensive private road network."Mr Sutton has been in a y correspondence with the Scottish Government over what he sees as its failure to keep track of the scale of the issue.A spokesman for the government said: "We do not collect information on roadsrsquo adoption status, as that is a matter for local authorities, who are responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of roads they have adopted."Un-adopted or private roads are the responsibility of housing developers or private home owners, who should consult their relevant local authority on adoption arrangements."

title: donald-findlay-qc-talks-distressing-toll-work
story: But Donald Findlay QC has, for the first time, told of the toll his work has taken, describing it as at times "distressing".The flamboyant advocate - known for puffing on his pipe and for his mutton-chop sideburns - has lead the defence in some of Scotlands most infamous murder cases, including Peter Tobin and Luke Mitchell.Now , he has also offered insight into the inspiration for his decision to pursue such a career, going back to his childhood in the s when he first read about the Scottish serial killer, Peter Manuel.Findlay, who hails from Cowdenbeath, Fe, opens up in a new BBC Scotland series, Crime Files, which begins on Sunday.Interviewed by renowned Scots criminologist, Professor David Wilson, he hints at harbouring regret over allowing his job to become his le - but suggests that it is now too late to change his ways.:Craig Whyte defender Donald Findlay named as highest earning legal aid advocateldquoIrsquove never really acquired any hobbies or interests or anything outwith the job," he says."Itrsquos constantly just a part of my le and has now been so for well over  years.ldquoI tell young lawyers who want to become involved in crime, it is a vocation because itrsquos not easy to defend some of the things we have to defend and yoursquove got to do it with a passion and yoursquove got to do it with a vigour.ldquoBut at the same time, you shouldnrsquot do what Irsquove done and let it become the be-all and end-all. Itrsquos too much. I know that now but itrsquos a bit late.He is, though,chairman of his hometown football club, Cowdenbeath FC, but admits there is ldquono pleasure in the role, adding: ldquoIf you look to see the record of Cowdenbeath... you will see that this is another burden I have to carry around with me.He also says that everyone is entitled to a defence, but admits there is a downside to his position: ldquoIf you believe in the legal system, you believe that everyone is entitled to a defence. Then you canrsquot pick and choose.ldquoYou canrsquot say, lsquoWell, Irsquoll defend somebody who does this, but Irsquom not going to defend somebody who commits a sexual offence or a mass murder, or whatever, because thatrsquos just not right."You take on somebody whorsquos accused of crime and you defend them in respect of that crime.But he admits to finding it ldquodficult sometimes due to how up-close-and-personal his position takes him to mans inhumanity to man.One of his most successful defences was that of former gangster Paul Ferris, who in  was found not guilty of all seven charges against him, including that of murdering Arthur Thompson Jr.He also defended Mitchell, who in  was sentenced to le imprisonment for murdering his -year-old girlfriend, Jodi Jones, and Tobin. Now , he will die in jail, having been convicted of the murders of Angelika Kluk in Glasgow in , Vicky Hamilton in  and Dina McNicol in .Tobin also features in the Crime Files series, in which Professor Wilson, who grew up in Carluke, maintains the killer is also infamous Barras dance hall murderer Bible John.:How Craig Whytes QC Donald Findlay had the fraud trial jury laughingFindlay says: ldquoI do worry. I worry about what is happening during a trial. I tend to take work home with me, and after a trialthe client has been convicted then I worry that perhaps I could or should have done better."But during a trial you do see some pretty horrendous things. Manrsquos inhumanity to man is pretty endless and you just have to harden yourself and look as it as best as you can as a piece of evidence.ldquoBut some things I have looked at can be quite distressing, involving dead children and so on.As a seven-year-old in the s, it was reading about Manuel that lead him toward his career. The US-born serial killer, who moved to Uddingston, Lanarkshire, was convicted of murdering seven people across Lanarkshire and southern Scotland between  and his arrest in January , but is thought to have murdered two more.Earlier this year, Findlay narrated an audiobook detailing the le of Manuel, who was taken to the gallows at Barlinnie in  after one of the most sensationalist trials in legal history that saw him sack his lawyers and conduct his own defence.When the -hour audiobook, Manuel: Portrait of a Serial Killer, was released, Findlay said: "The Manuel case fascinated me since I was a child. As a seven-year-old, I read every word that was reported."The challenge of representing someone faced with so many serious charges is one of the reasons I became a defence lawyer."Findlay also says during the programme that the increasing use of science by prosecutors in court cases is a "very real concern", in part because some can form views by watching TV.He says: ldquoOne problem is, members of the public get a lot of their science from CSI: Miami and New York and all these kind of things. And thatrsquos not real. But thatrsquos the impression you get.ldquoPeople think itrsquos as simple as that but, of course, itrsquos not. So you really have to understand science, you have to be wary of science because therersquos a lot of junk science out there."Crime Files begins on Sunday on BBC Scotland at pm.

title: let-s-try-create-cycle-acceptance
story: THE benefits of cycling are hard to dispute ndash improved physical and mental health, saving money and a dependable commute time plus improved air quality, reduced climate change emissions, less congestion and greater local economic spend.Unfortunately, some people resent those who travel by bike and serious injuries to people riding are increasing in parallel with the rise in cycling. So how can we try and change our culture to a more cycling-friendly one Therersquos no quick solution to this one, but after infrastructure and enforcement, education is a key element of an effective road safety strategy because misconceptions and myths about cycling contribute to a culture of conflict on the roads.ldquoCyclists donrsquot pay road tax is a statement often used to explain why some people feel they, as drivers, have more rights on the roads. The reality is road tax ended in the s, and we all pay for the roads through general or local taxation. Vehicle Excise Duty is based on vehicle emissions .A second myth is that there isnrsquot cycle proficiency training in schools any more. In reality, Bikeability Scotland cycling training is giving children the skills and confidence to cycle safely. At least , children are trained each year and all children are able to receive free training.Another common misunderstanding is over road positioning. You should cycle away from the gutter. Itrsquos legal to cycle in the middle of the lane and sometimes itrsquos the safest place, For instancethe road is narrow and itrsquos unsafe for a car to pass, when approaching a junction or to avoid potholes or doors of parked cars being opened in your path.We often hear the argument that bad behaviour, or perceived arrogance, from people cycling provokes careless or dangerous driving and that safety would improveldquocyclists behaved better. Red-light running, to take an oft-cited example of cycling behaviour, is wrong, whether cycling or driving, and too many people do it. But itrsquos not acceptable or logical to hold all people cycling responsible simply because they use the same mode of transport. ldquoCyclists are not a homogenous group but inidual people, just as drivers are.The fact is that many people who cycle are being intimidated, injured or worse, while cycling correctly. And are we really suggesting that someone who is cycling irresponsibly deserves a near-death experience Ultimately, resentful attitudes towards ldquocyclists shouldnrsquot influence actual driving behaviour. People on bikes are undeniably more vulnerable on roads than people in vehicles. Driving too close is a careless or dangerous driving offence because it can kill or seriously injure someone.Almost everyonersquos behaviour ndash including some people who cycle ndash has room for improvement to create a cycle of acceptance, and remove the perception of two tribes going to war on the roads or shared use paths.ldquoWhat about them  Deal with their behaviour first  is never an excuse for careless or dangerous behaviour by anyone. Myths and misconceptions about people cycling need to be banished and enforcement has to focus on the behaviours with greatest potential for harm, just as the Police Operation Close Pass does. Expanding cycling infrastructure is the key priority, creating dedicated space for cycling, to the benefit of everyone.We have a long way to go but quick change is possible. With the increased investment in cycle infrastructure, an increased focus on access to bikes, and greater education and understanding to create a cycle of acceptance, a cycling-friendly nation is no longer an impossible dream.

title: alan-roden-tensions-london-edinburgh-going-get-far-worse
story: Discovering how well this had gone down with the easily pleased hacks, Scottish Secretary Jim Murphy tried to outdo him the following year by providing a slap-up curry at his own festive bash.This was before austerity started to bite and relationships soured: by the time Mr Salmond left office, journalists were treated to bowls of crisps in the basement of St Andrewrsquos House.:Marianne Taylor: The SNP is right to back abortion in Northern IrelandBut during the three years when Scotland had an SNP government in Edinburgh, and a Labour government in Westminster, there was a newfound rivalry between the Scottish Government and the Scotland Office.Until Mr Murphy took over, the job of Scottish Secretary had ndash literally ndash been part-time.When the future Scottish Labour leader was appointed by Gordon Brown, it became the full-time role it is today.According to SNP figures, communications staffing costs for the Scotland Office have soared from around pound, in - to over pound, a decade later, and yesterday there was a fresh row about the departmentrsquos spending on overseas travel.The Nationalists have said this is justication to abolish the department, complaining that itrsquos spending public money "pumping out propaganda" promoting Scotlandrsquos place in the UK.The reality, of course, is that this is what governments do. The Scottish Government is also spending public money promoting Scotland with its effective "Scotland is Now" tourism campaign ndash ostensibly aimed at a global market, but clearly serving a dual purpose by suggesting to the domestic market that Scotlandrsquos values are distinct.The political tensions that started under Salmond and Murphy have continued, with present incumbent David Mundell facing near-weekly calls from the SNP to resign, often without much of an explanation as to why he should fall on his sword.Intergovernmental relations between the UK and Scottish governments are "under pressure like never before", according to SNP MP Pete Wishart.Mr Wishart acknowledged that work between civil servants is "conducted perfectly well", and that is certainly what those behind the scenes insist is the case.If there is a problem, then, itrsquos among the politicians, and thatrsquos hardly surprising ndash and not really anything new.It takes two to tango.:Scottish Government cannot guarantee medicine supplies under no-deal BrexitThe SNPrsquos well-worn narrative about a dysal Westminster system doesnrsquot stand up to scrutinythe political leaders work in harmony together. There is every reason for the SNP to be perfectly happy that intergovernmental relations are considered "under pressure like never before".After all, the Scottish Governmentrsquos stated aim is independence and the abolition of intergovernmental relations with the UK.But the UK Governmentrsquos stated aim is to preserve the Union, so it is unsurprising that the role of the Scotland Office has steadily increased over the years.Andtensions are strained now, itrsquos only going to get far worse.One of Theresa Mayrsquos final acts of her premiership was to announce a review of the way the UK Government handles the current devolved settlement.That doesnrsquot mean a shake-up of powers as some initially thought it means a sht in mindset for every single UK Government department.Today, Whitehall civil servants are told to ensure their work fits in with the devolution arrangement ndash is the Scottish Government kept engaged  How does the Sewel Convention apply In the future, the questions will be: Does our work strengthen the Union  Or does it potentially advance the case of independence ndash andso, letrsquos think again.Will it make the UK civil service more politicised  Probably.But that happened long ago here in Scotland.Last year, the Scottish Tories complained that civil servants were contacting witnesses ahead of appearances at a Holyrood committee, and highlighted graphics being tweeted by Government accounts which "used the SNPrsquos party political language".Valid concerns at the time, but such complaints are likely to appear hypocritical in the near future.And itrsquos not just civil servants who are being told to change their mindset ndash Cabinet ministers are too.The message is clear:the Union is to be saved, the UK Government needs to loosen its purse strings in Scotland, as The Herald exclusively revealed last week.That includes splashing the cash in both reserved and devolved areas ndash the Edinburgh City Deal for example has delivered cash for the capitalrsquos university and the UK Government is helping fund Edinburghrsquos new concert hall, even though culture is devolved.The argument is that such a venue is of cultural importance for the entire UK. Expect much more of the same to follow.Current Chancellor Philip Hammond has been a bulwark against this ever since he moved into Number , arguing that itrsquos unfair on English taxpayers as Scotland already receives its share of funding through the Barnett formula.It means spending money twice over north of the Border, he complains, with some justication.But the order has now gone out loud and clear that this is the price to pay to save the Union.And nobody has done more to achieve this mindset change than David Mundell.He has spent years quietly and effectively persuading his Cabinet colleagues of the risk to the Union and explaining to Whitehall departments they must learn to understand devolution.Next week, just moments before Theresa Mayrsquos final PMQs before she heads to the palace will be the last Scottish Questions before summer.No fan of Boris Johnson, it could be Mr Mundellrsquos last appearance at the despatch box.ButPrime Minister Johnson wants to avoid going down in history as the man who lost the Union, he would be well advised to consider keeping Mr Mundell in post.He should ask himself who does Nicola Sturgeon want as Scottish Secretary  The assured David Mundell or a maverick like Ross Thomson  The First Minister would surely prefer the latter.But whoever is Scottish Secretary, the role is now crucial to Scotlandrsquos constitutional future.Itrsquos a far cry from the part-time job it was before the SNP stormed to power.There will be more money to spend in Scotland far greater UK Government involvement in Scotland ndash and more explosive political rows with the SNP as a result.The great unknown is which government will emerge as the political winner in this latest constitutional battle.

title: worst-airline-uk-flight-delays-revealed
story: The Spanish carrierrsquos UK departures were  minutes late on average in , according to analysis of Civil Aviation Authoritydata by the PA news agency.Thomas Cook Airlines was found to have the second worst performance with flights typically  minutes late, followed by Wizz Air , Norwegian Air UKand Eurowings .:Holidays from hell: your consumer rightsNorwegian Air UK is a British subsidiary of Norwegian Air Shuttle, operating transatlantic flights from Gatwick Airport.Cathay Pacic Airways is the most punctual airline, with aircraft typically taking off just eight minutes behind schedule.The average delay across all flights was  minutes.The ranking features the  airlines with more than , flights from UK airports last year.Average delay figures take into account every flight that operated, including those that were on time. Cancelled services are excluded from the CAA data.Strikes by air traffic controllers caused havoc for airlines last summer.A spokesman for Vueling, which serves several UK airports including Heathrow, Gatwick, Edinburgh and Birmingham, said the low-cost airlinersquos punctuality was ldquohugely affected by industrial action in France.He went on: ldquoThere were  strike days at Marseille last summer.ldquoDuring these strikes, Vueling flights to and from Barcelona and the UK could not fly straight across France but instead flew south of the Pyrenees and into the Atlantic before looping back towards Britain.ldquoAll airlines have been affected by air traffic control issues in Europe, but the location of Vuelingrsquoshub close to Marseille means it has been particularly badly affected.:Edinburgh and Glasgow Airport amongst worst for flight delays in the UKHe added that the airline has taken measures to mitigate against the impact of further ATC issues, such as allocating up to  spare aircraft to operate flights during disruption.Vuelingrsquos parent company is International Airlines Group, which also owns British Airways, Aer Lingus, Iberia and Level.Tim Alderslade, chief executive of trade body Airlines UK, which represents UK-registered carriers, said too many flights are affected by the countryrsquos ldquoantiquated airspace.He added: ldquoWe support Government in its efforts to introduce much needed modernisation so we can continue to safely and effectively accommodate the ever rising demand for air travel.Whereas many train companies pay compensation for delays of more than  minutes, airline passengers are only entitled to a pay out under European Union rulesthey arrive at their destination more than three hours late.Carriers can also avoid paying outthe disruption was due to ldquoextraordinary circumstances such as severe weather or a security alert.Consumer magazine Which  Travelrsquos Naomi Leach said flight delays can leave holidaymakers ldquohundreds of pounds out of pocket because of missed connections, transfers and fines for picking up their hire car late.She added:ldquoThe worst airlines need to ensure they have the staff and capacity to run an on-time service ndash and that they look after their customersdelays do occur.

title: lewis-capaldi-admits-love-noel-gallagher-collaboration-amid-spat

title: mathematician-alan-turing-feature-new-50-note
story: The selection of the mathematician, who is often credited as being the father of computer science, was announced at theScience and Industry Museum in Manchester.Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, who made the announcement, alsorevealed the imagery depicting Turing and his work that will be used for the reverse of the note.:Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedThe new polymer pound note is expected to enter circulation by the end of .It will feature a quote from Turing, given in an interview to the Times newspaper on June  : ldquoThis is only a foretaste of what is to come, and only the shadow of what is going to be.Turing waschosen following the Bankrsquos character selection process which included advice from scientic experts.In , the Banknote Character Advisory Committee chose to celebrate the field of science on the pound note, and members of the public were invited to put forward names over a six-week period.The Bank received a total of , nominations, covering  eligible figures.A shortlist was drawn up by the committee, with the Governor making the final decision.The Bank said theshortlist demonstrated the breadth of scientic achievement in the UK, from astronomy to physics, chemistry to palaeontology and mathematics to biochemistry.Those considered alongside Turing were Stephen Hawking, Mary Anning, Paul Dirac, Rosalind Franklin, William Herschel and Caroline Herschel, Dorothy Hodgkin, Ada Lovelace and Charles Babbage, James Clerk Maxwell, Srinivasa Ramanujan, Ernest Rutherford, and Frederick Sanger.:Judy Murrays Scottish banknotes refused in London bakersMr Carney said: ldquoAlan Turing was an outstanding mathematician whose work has had an enormous impact on how we live today.ldquoAs the father of computer science and articial intelligence, as well as war hero, Alan Turingrsquos contributions were far-ranging and path-breaking. Turing is a giant on whose shoulders so many now stand.While Turing is perhaps best-known for his work devising code-breaking machines during the Second World War, which was portrayed in a film starring Benedict Cumberbatch, he played a pivotal role in the development of early computers first at the National Physical Laboratory and later at the University of Manchester.He laid the foundations for work on articial intelligence by considering the question of whether machines could think.Turing was homosexual and was posthumously pardoned by the Queen, having been convicted of gross indecency for his relationship with a man.Have you heard  Wersquore looking for a scientist to be the face of the new pound note. And we want your help. Tell us who you think it should be and nominate today: https:t.co kXlMLaC #ThinkScience #poundnote pic SMZoxxAEimdash Bank of EnglandNovember , The new design will featurea photo of Turing taken in , which is part of the Photographs Collection at the National Portrait Gallery.There will also be atable and mathematical formulae from a  paper by Turing whichis widely recognised as being a foundation for computer science.It sought to establish whether there could be a definitive method by which something could be assessed as provable or not using a universal machine.The design will also feature technical drawings for the British Bombe ndash one of the main methods used to break Enigma-enciphered messages during the Second World War.Turingrsquos signature from the visitorsrsquo book at Bletchley Park in , where he worked during the war, will also be included, alongside ticker tape depicting Turingrsquos birth date ndash June   ndash in binary code.The concept of a machine fed by binary tape featured in Turingrsquos  paper.The current pound note, which was first issued in , features leading lights of the Industrial RevolutionMatthew Boulton and James Watt.Bank of England Chief Cashier Sarah John said: ldquoThe strength of the shortlist is testament to the UKrsquos incredible scientic contribution.ldquoThe breadth of iniduals and achievements reflects the huge range of nominations we received for this note and I would to thank the public for all their suggestions of scientists we could celebrate.

title: calls-snp-outline-alternative-proposals-independence-new-prime-minister-blocks-referendum
story: SNP MP Angus MacNeil and the partys group leader on Inverclyde Council, Christopher McEleny, wanted their plan to be debated at the SNP conference in October where it could have become official party policy.It calls for a vote on independence to take place by autumn , and states thatthe UK Government fails to grant a Section  order to enable this to happen, voters ing a majority of independence-supporting MSPs or Scottish MPs would give a mandate to the Scottish Government to start independence negotiations.The proposers believe this could have provided a way around the next prime minister refusing to grant permission for a second independence referendum, as both Conservative leadership candidates oppose a further vote.However, the resolution for debate has not been selected as part of the provisional agenda for the SNP autumn conference.In a joint statement, Mr MacNeil and Mr McEleny said: "We are disappointed that it has been deemed that debating a credible plan on how to progress the case for actually delivering independence isnt worthy of the agenda at SNP conference.:Boris Johnsons tax plans could spell disaster"When the Scottish Government request a Section  order we know the answer is going to be No."Our plan set out a means of ensuring Scotlands voice was heard, and it progressed our mandate for a referendum as it should be deployed, with democratic determination."The plan received much support from across Scotland, therefore we are looking forward to the party leadership now setting out their plan B to ensure that Scotlands destiny does not depend on the mood and vagaries of the UK Government, but of the Scottish people."The Scottish Government now has to show leadership on this issue and conference must be given a roadmap as to how the leadership believe we will deliver independence.:Scottish Government cannot guarantee medicine supplies under no-deal Brexit"Meanwhile it surely is past time, three years after the Brexit referendum, that a focused campaign on independence is launched with Scot Gov backing - merely announcing legislation through the parliament as was done in April is not enough."An SNP spokeswoman said: "The process of producing the provisional agenda is the internal business of the Scottish National Party, with motions shortlisted by a democratically elected internal body."The SNP already has a cast-iron mandate for holding an independence referendum before the  election, and the First Minister has made clear that she believes this should take place in the second half of next year."

title: new-tourist-trail-world
story: Scotlands links to the cosmos are being highlighted with a new tourist trail celebrating everything from a glen twinned with a rocky outcrop on Mars to the unrivalled chance to see the stars in all their glory at the countrys Dark Skies parks.The Scotland is Out of this World trail features Scottish connections to each of the planets in the solar system, as well as facts and details of science centres and the best places to stargaze.It is being launched to celebrate both the th anniversary of the Moon Landings this Saturday, and the th anniversary of the founding of VisitScotland itself.Malcolm Roughead, Chief Executive of VisitScotland, said: ldquoFor  years VisitScotland has helped position Scotland as a must-visit destination to audiences across the world."It is therefore fitting that in our anniversary year we set our sights even further and travelled into space in what can only be described as a truly lsquoout of this worldrsquo campaign."While Scotland did not participate in the Space race which saw Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and module pilot Michael Collins reach the moon in , Caledonias connection to space runs surprisingly deep.Braemar, Aberdeenshire, features on the trial as the birthplace of the astronomer Johann Lamont, the first person to calculate the mass of Uranus.:World prepares to celebrate  years since man walked on moonAcross the country in Jedburgh, in the Borders, th century science writer Mary Somerville was also inspired by the heavens, correctly predicting that dficulties in calculating the position of Uranus pointed to an undiscovered planet - an observation which led the discovery of Neptune. Scotland has also provided name to some of the features found on our nearest celestial neighbours - a future visitor to Venus would be able to walk on Maxwell Montes, the planetrsquos only feature named after a man.It was christened in honour of the great Scottish ndashphysicist James Clerk Maxwell, and the trail visits his resting place at Parton, Dumfries  Galloway.Meanwhile on Mars, one of NASAs remote rovers has already trundled through Glenelg, a geological feature twinned with the Highlands village twinned.The Out of this World map also encourages tourists to see Loch Airigh on the Isle of Harris, which stands in for the planet Jupiter in the  Stanley Kubrick film, : A Space Odyssey.Mr Roughead added: ldquoScotland is Out of this World offered the opportunity to delve into the past and celebrate the countryrsquos contribution to space exploration and astronomy and its ancestral links to one of the greatest moments in history.ldquoThe new trail reveals some of the countryrsquos stellar attractions and locations to visit to firmly cement Scotlandrsquos place in astro-tourism."After all, our best views arenrsquot confined to our awe-inspiring landscapes, but reach up high into the night sky above as well.:The global sense of wonder that greeted a giant leap for mankind,  years ago#Visitors north of the border can find two International Dark Sky Parks - Galloway Forest Park in Dumfries and Galloway and Tomintoul and Glenlivet in Cairngorms National Park - a Dark Sky Islandand a Dark Sky Town .As part of theScotland is Out of this World campaign, VisitScotland teamed up with Sent Into Space to launch the worlds Highland Coosmonaut , metres into near space wearing an Armstrong tartan spacesuit, in honour of the first man on the moon.Footage of the cuddly toy - dubbed BuzzBograve - lting off by weather balloon from Gilnockie Tower, the ancestral home of Clan Armstrong, and landing safely near Cranshaws in the Scottish Borders, has been released today.BuzzBograve was named by -year-old Peter Lunan, of Dunblane, whose entry was picked by the national tourism organisation in its national Name the Highland Coosmonaut competition.:China will land humans on Mars lsquowithin a decadersquoThe name derives from Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on the Moon, and the Gaelic word for cow Bograve. The Highland Coosmonaut will be on display over the summer at the Edinburgh iCentre on the Royal Mile.Alex Keen, Head of Communications and Launch Specialist from Sent into Space, said: ldquoLaunching at Gilnockie Tower was a real treat, given its connections to Clan Armstrong. It was fantastic to work with the team from VisitScotland and we were blown away by the beautul and dramatic landscape we crossed as we pursued the Coosmonaut."Once the Coosmonaut was back in our hands, we were genuinely sad to have to leave and head back to England.

title: cigar-loving-tory-mp-39-s-constituency-lowest-smoking-rate
story: The SNP seat, represented at Westminster by Martin John Docherty-Hughes MP, was ranked th for smoking prevalence out of  constituencies across Scotland, England and Wales -  being the highest.Research found that . per cent of the population there were smokers compared to a UK average of .%.The Britain-wide smoking map demonstrates the links between deprivation and higher smoking prevalence, with the highest rates consistently found in poorer areas.: Children in poor areas six times more likely to be exposed to tobacco retailingWest Dunbartonshire has long battled problems linked to deprivation, whereas the affluent Conservative-held seat of East Renfrewshire is ranked as having the lowest percentage of smokers -
